Hold on, sometimes "before" can be interpreted as including the same day depending on context, but usually, it's considered after. However, in many cases, "before" might mean earlier than or equal to, but I think in some contexts, it could mean strictly before. So I need to clarify that.

Wait, no, actually, if the date of appointment is exactly July 10, 2010, then saying "before 10 july 2010" would technically include that day because sometimes appointments can happen on the exact day a coach is fired or something. Wait, actually, if someone is appointed on the same day as the outgoing coach leaves, that might be considered "on" the date rather than "before". Alternatively, maybe "before" can include the same day in some contexts, so I'm a bit confused here. But generally, if you say something happens before a specific date, it doesn't include the date itself. So if the appointment was made on July 10, it's not before that date.
